This
On
Week
List
Fiction
HANNIBAL, by Thomas Harris. (Dell, $7.99.) Seven years after his escape, the fiendish psychiatrist Hannibal Lecter is still at large.
WHILE I WAS GONE, by Sue Miller. (Ballantine, $12.95.) A small-town veterinarian, the wife of a minister, begins a flirtation with an old friend.
IRISH HEARTS, by Nora Roberts. (Silhouette, $7.50.) Two previously published novels, now in one volume, about Irishwomen's lives in America.
TOM CLANCY'S OP-CENTER: Divide and Conquer, created by Tom Clancy and Steve Pieczenik; written by Jeff Rovin. (Berkley, $7.99.) Traitors try to oust the president.
IRISH REBEL, by Nora Roberts. (Silhouette, $4.50.) The latest novel in a series about Irish families in America.
ECLIPSE BAY, by Jayne Ann Krentz. (Jove, $7.50.) A man and a woman, whose Oregon families are engaged in a longtime feud, fall in love.
RIVER'S END, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) The daughter of a glamorous Hollywood couple must cope with her family's horrifying past.
THE BLUEST EYE, by Toni Morrison. (Plume, $12.95.) The story of an 11-year-old black girl -- pregnant by her father -- who prays for blue eyes.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Scholastic, $5.99.) A British boy attends a school for witchcraft.
PEARL COVE, by Elizabeth Lowell. (Avon, $7.50.) Seeking help in solving the mystery of her husband's death, a woman finds romance.
THE TESTAMENT, by John Grisham. (Island, $7.99.) A billionaire, a lawyer and a missionary are brought together by a startling secret.
*TOMORROW'S PROMISE, by Sandra Brown. (Mira, $6.99.) A woman learns that her husband, long missing in action, may be alive.
TRANSFER OF POWER, by Vince Flynn. (Pocket, $6.99.) A terrorist group descends on the White House and captures nearly 100 hostages.
*THE SAVING GRACES, by Patricia Gaffney. (HarperTorch, $6.99.) The close friendship that binds four women is put to the test.
ACTS OF MALICE, by Perri O'Shaughnessy. (Island, $7.50.) Nina Reilly defends a man accused of murdering his brother on the ski slopes of Lake Tahoe.

This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
THE PERFECT STORM, by Sebastian Junger. (HarperPerennial, $14; HarperPaperbacks, $6.99.) The story of the northeaster of 1991.
THE SEAT OF THE SOUL, by Gary Zukav. (Fireside/S&S, $12.) How daily activities can be enhanced by feelings of meaning and purpose. (+)
EVERY MAN A TIGER, by Tom Clancy with Chuck Horner. (Berkley, $16.95.) The novelist and a retired Air Force general examine the gulf war.
*THE HUNGRY OCEAN, by Linda Greenlaw. (Hyperion, $14.) A sea captain's account of her 30-day swordfishing voyage off the Northeast coast.
A WALK IN THE WOODS, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $13.) A journalist finds beauty and humor while hiking the Appalachian Trail.
*GIRL, INTERRUPTED, by Susanna Kaysen. (Vintage, $12.) A memoir of a young woman's mental illness.
I'M A STRANGER HERE MYSELF, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $14.) The author describes what it's like to return to the United States after living abroad for two decades.
*THE MAJORS, by John Feinstein. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) A sportswriter reports on the 1998 Masters, U.S. Open, British Open and P.G.A. golf tournaments.
A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived his mother's abuse. (+)
ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Touchstone/S&S, $14 and $7.99.) An Irish-American writer recalls his childhood in Limerick.
THE FIRST WORLD WAR, by John Keegan. (Vintage, $16.) A military historian recounts the 1914-18 conflict.
THE LOST BOY, by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $10.95.) The author of ''A Child Called 'It' ''recalls his life in foster homes. (+)
*THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor, $15.) A journalist explains the instant electronic global economy.
*THE ELEGANT UNIVERSE, by Brian Greene. (Vintage, $15.) A presentation of superstring theory.
*BELLA TUSCANY, by Frances Mayes. (Broadway, $15.) An American remembers a spring and summer spent in the romantic sections of Italy.

List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous
CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE TEENAGE SOUL III, compiled by Jack Canfield, Mark Victor Hansen and Kimberly Kirberger. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Inspirational stories. (+)
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $15.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich.
DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (Avon, $14 and $6.99.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)
TAKE TIME FOR YOUR LIFE, by Cheryl Richardson. (Broadway, $13.) A seven-step program for enhancing one's social, financial and spiritual well-being.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending June 17, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some stores received bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.
